nodes.text: Sponsors and investigators shall not promote investigational drugs as safe or effective
Scientific findings about investigational drugs may be disseminated through scientific or lay media
Sponsors and investigators shall not commercially distribute investigational drugs
Sponsors and investigators shall not test market investigational drugs
Sponsors shall not unduly prolong investigations after sufficient data exists for marketing application
Sponsors must meet charging requirements for clinical trials per paragraph (b)
Sponsors must justify the amount to be charged for investigational drugs
Sponsors must obtain prior written FDA authorization to charge for investigational drugs
FDA will withdraw charging authorization if it interferes with drug development
Sponsor's drug must demonstrate potential clinical benefit advantage over available products
Regulatory references in this part apply to chapter I of title 21 CFR unless otherwise noted
Clinical trial data must be essential for establishing drug effectiveness or safety for initial approval
Clinical trial data must support significant labeling changes for approved drugs
Sponsors must demonstrate extraordinary drug costs to justify charging for clinical trials
Charging duration may continue for the length of the clinical trial unless FDA specifies shorter period
Sponsors must ensure charging won't interfere with drug marketing approval development
Treatment IND/protocol expanded access charging requires reasonable assurance of non-interference
Show evidence of sufficient enrollment in ongoing clinical trials needed for marketing approval
Demonstrate adequate progress in drug development for marketing approval
Submit development milestones planned for the next year in the investigational plan
Charging authorization is limited to the specified number of patients approved for treatment use
Charging for expanded access is limited to 1 year unless FDA specifies shorter period
Sponsors may only recover direct costs specifically attributed to providing the authorized drug
Direct costs for charging must only include drug acquisition costs from other manufacturers
Direct costs for charging must include shipping and handling costs for the drug
Indirect commercial production costs cannot be included in charging costs
Research, development and administrative costs cannot be included in charging costs
Sponsors may recover IND monitoring costs for expanded access programs
Sponsors must provide documentation supporting cost recovery calculations
Cost calculations must be reviewed and approved by an independent certified public accountant
Waiver requests may be submitted in an IND or IND amendment
Emergency waiver requests may be made by telephone or rapid communication
Waiver requests must include explanation of non-compliance, alternative action, or other justification
FDA may grant waivers if non-compliance poses no significant risk to human subjects
Sponsor must submit IND to FDA before conducting clinical investigation with investigational new drug
Clinical investigations cannot begin until IND is in effect per § 312.40
Separate IND required for clinical investigations with informed consent exceptions under § 50.24
FDA must provide written determination within 30 days of receiving IND with informed consent exception
Clinical investigations with informed consent exceptions require prior written FDA authorization
IND may be submitted for one or more investigation phases
Phase 1 studies must monitor drug metabolism and pharmacologic actions in humans
Phase 1 studies should obtain sufficient pharmacokinetic data to design Phase 2 studies
Phase 1 studies should include 20-80 total subjects
Phase 2 studies must evaluate drug effectiveness for specific indications in patients
Phase 2 studies must determine common short-term side effects and risks
Phase 2 studies should involve no more than several hundred subjects
Phase 3 studies must include several hundred to several thousand subjects
FDA must assure safety and rights of subjects in all investigation phases
FDA must assess scientific quality of Phase 2 and 3 clinical investigations
Phase 2 and 3 investigations must yield data capable of meeting marketing approval standards
IND submissions must contain sufficient drug information to accomplish safety and effectiveness objectives
Preliminary evidence of drug effectiveness must be obtained before Phase 3 studies
IRB must review and approve informed consent forms when DOD determines consent may be obtained
Initial IND submission should focus on general investigational plan and human study protocols
Protocol amendments should build logically on previous submissions
Annual IND reports should report status of ongoing studies
Annual IND reports should update the investigational plan for coming year
Sponsors should follow IND format in § 312.23 routinely
Sponsor-investigators may refer to manufacturer's IND if authorized by manufacturer
Submit FDA Form-1571 cover sheet with IND application
Include sponsor name, address, phone number, date and investigational drug name on cover sheet
Identify clinical investigation phases on IND cover sheet
Commit to not begin clinical investigations until IND is in effect
Commit to IRB review and approval of all studies in clinical investigation
Report proposed research activity changes to IRB per part 56 requirements
Name and title of person monitoring clinical investigation conduct must be specified
Name and title of person responsible for drug safety evaluation must be documented
Document CRO name, address and transferred obligations for any outsourced clinical studies
Application must be signed by sponsor or authorized representative
Non-US signatories must have US-based attorney/agent countersign the IND
Provide introductory statement with drug name and all active ingredients
Include summary of previous human experience with the drug
Report any drug withdrawals from any country related to safety/effectiveness
Provide overall plan for investigating drug product for following year
Include rationale for drug study and indications to be studied
Specify estimated number of patients for planned studies
The investigator's brochure must include a description of the drug substance and formulation with structural formula
The brochure must summarize pharmacological and toxicological effects in animals and humans
The brochure must summarize pharmacokinetics and biological disposition data from animal and human studies
The brochure must include safety and effectiveness information from prior clinical studies
The brochure must describe anticipated risks, side effects and required monitoring based on prior experience
A protocol must be submitted for each planned study in the IND
Phase 1 protocols should provide an outline with estimated number of patients
Phase 1 protocols must specify safety monitoring details for vital signs and blood chemistry
Phase 1 protocol modifications not affecting safety assessments must be reported in annual report
Phase 2 and 3 protocols should include detailed descriptions of all study aspects
Protocols must include a statement of study objectives and purpose
Protocols must include investigator name, address and qualifications
Provide name and qualifications of each investigator and subinvestigator
Document name and address of research facilities to be used
Document name and address of each reviewing Institutional Review Board
Define patient selection and exclusion criteria
Describe methods to minimize bias from subjects, investigators and analysts
Submit sufficient information to identify drug substance and ensure quality, purity, and strength
Initial Phase 1 submissions should focus on raw materials and new drug substance identification/control
Final specifications for drug substance and product must be provided by end of investigation
Submit stability data showing drug substance/product are within acceptable limits for investigation duration
Amount of information submitted should align with scope of proposed clinical investigation
Submit information amendments for expanded chemistry and manufacturing controls when scaling up clinical trials
Provide description of drug substance including physical, chemical and biological characteristics
Include name and address of drug substance manufacturer
Document acceptable limits and analytical methods for drug substance identity, strength, quality and purity
Provide stability information for drug substance during toxicological and clinical studies
List all components used in manufacturing the investigational drug product
Informed consent must describe foreseeable risks and discomforts
Document quantitative composition of investigational drug product including expected variations
Provide name and address of drug product manufacturer
Include description of manufacturing and packaging procedures appropriate for the product
Document acceptable limits and analytical methods for drug identity, strength, quality and purity
Provide information to assure product stability during planned clinical studies
Include description of composition, manufacture and control of placebos used in controlled trials
Submit information identifying individuals who evaluated study results and concluded safety
Document where investigations were conducted and records are available for inspection
Submit informational amendments with additional safety data as drug development proceeds
Describe pharmacological effects and mechanisms of action in animals
Document drug absorption, distribution, metabolism and excretion data if known
Provide integrated summary of toxicological effects in animals and in vitro
Include clinical trial registry statement in consent documents for applicable trials
Provide full tabulated data for each toxicology study supporting clinical investigation safety
Include statement of GLP compliance for each nonclinical laboratory study under part 58
Provide reason for non-compliance if study does not follow GLP regulations
Submit summary of all previous human experience with investigational drug
Include detailed information about previous investigations or marketing in US or other countries
Provide detailed information from controlled trials relevant to drug effectiveness
Physicians may provide emergency care as permitted by Federal, State or local law
Provide full published material relevant to safety of proposed investigation
Provide full published material relevant to drug effectiveness assessment
Submit information for each active component in combination drugs
List all countries where drug has been marketed outside US
List countries where drug was withdrawn for safety/effectiveness reasons
Submit drug dependence and abuse potential information for psychotropic substances
Research must include provisions to protect subject privacy and data confidentiality
FDA may disqualify non-compliant IRBs or institutions
Submit new drug applications according to Part 314
Submit bioavailability/bioequivalence data for human drugs per Part 320
Submit product development protocol for medical devices according to section 515
Sponsors may recover IND reporting costs for expanded access programs
IND application must include a table of contents
Members with conflicts of interest must not participate in project reviews
IRBs may invite subject matter experts to assist with complex reviews
Document planned drug dosage, maximum dose and duration of patient exposure
Describe procedures and tests to monitor drug effects and minimize risk to subjects
IRB may waive written consent for minimal risk research not normally requiring written consent
IRB may grant exception from informed consent requirements for emergency research under § 50.24
Provide copies of all labels and labeling to each investigator
Phase 1 studies of radioactive drugs must include data for dosimetry calculations
Submit radiation-absorbed dose calculations for whole body and critical organs for radioactive drugs
Include plans for assessing pediatric safety and effectiveness
Submit additional information if requested by FDA for application review
References to previously submitted information must identify file name, reference number, volume and page number
References to third-party submissions require signed authorization from original submitter
Submit accurate and complete English translation of all non-English IND parts
Submit original literature publications for any translated documents
Submit one original and two copies of all IND submissions, amendments and reports
Amend IND as needed to ensure clinical investigations follow included protocols
Submit separate IND for clinical investigations with emergency research informed consent exceptions
IRB must document written procedures as required by § 56.108
IRB must maintain statements of significant new findings provided to subjects
Initial IND submissions must be numbered 000
Subsequent IND submissions must be numbered chronologically with three-digit numbers
Sponsors must identify exceptions from informed consent under §50.24 on the cover sheet
New study protocols not covered by existing IND must be submitted to FDA as protocol amendments
New study protocols must be approved by the IRB before study begins
Changes affecting subject safety in Phase 1 protocols must be submitted as protocol amendments
Submit protocol amendments for any increase in drug dosage or duration of exposure
Submit protocol amendments for significant increases in number of study subjects
Submit amendments for significant protocol design changes like adding/dropping control groups
Submit amendments when adding new safety monitoring procedures or tests
Submit protocol changes to FDA for review
Obtain IRB approval for protocol changes
Protocol amendments for immediate hazards must be subsequently notified to FDA
Protocol amendments for immediate hazards must be notified to reviewing IRB per §56.104(c)
Sponsor must submit protocol amendment when adding new investigator except for treatment protocols
Sponsor must notify FDA within 30 days of adding new investigator
Protocol amendments must be prominently identified with specific amendment type labels
New protocol amendments must include copy of protocol and description of key differences
Submit protocol amendments before implementing any new protocol or protocol changes
Reference specific technical information in IND to support clinically significant protocol changes
Identify location of referenced IND information by name, reference number, volume and page number
Submit new investigator additions and investigator information updates at 30-day intervals
Group multiple protocol/change submissions into a single submission when feasible
Specify questions for FDA comment when requesting FDA feedback on submissions
Sponsor shall report essential IND information via information amendment when not covered by other reports
Information amendments must prominently identify their contents with appropriate headers
Information amendments must include a statement of nature and purpose
Information amendments must contain organized data in scientific review format
Information amendments should not be submitted more frequently than every 30 days
Submit technical information supporting IND unless referenced from scientific literature
IND must contain introductory statement and general investigational plan
Document any anticipated severe or serious risks based on toxicology
Phase 1 study protocols may be less detailed than Phase 2 and 3 protocols
Submit environmental analysis requirements or claim categorical exclusion
Significant changes to Phase 2 or 3 protocols must be submitted as protocol amendments
Protocol change amendments must describe changes and reference original submission
Sponsor must report new toxicology, chemistry or technical information via information amendment
Sponsor must report discontinuance of clinical investigation via information amendment
Life-threatening adverse events must be reported if they place patient at immediate risk of death
Death outcomes must be classified as serious adverse events
Inpatient hospitalization or prolonged stays must be classified as serious adverse events
Significant incapacity or disruption of normal functions must be classified as serious adverse events
Congenital anomalies and birth defects must be classified as serious adverse events
Medical events requiring intervention to prevent serious outcomes may be classified as serious adverse events
Report any adverse event with reasonable possibility of being caused by the drug as a suspected adverse reaction
List all expected adverse events and their severity levels in the investigator brochure
Classify adverse events as unexpected if severity exceeds levels documented in investigator brochure
Document risk information in general investigational plan if no investigator brochure exists
Classify adverse events as unexpected if not consistent with documented risk information
Sponsor must promptly review all safety information from foreign and domestic sources
Sponsor must review safety data from clinical and epidemiological investigations
Sponsor must review safety data from animal and in vitro studies
Sponsor must review scientific literature and unpublished papers for safety information
Sponsor must notify FDA and investigators of potential serious risks within 15 calendar days
Sponsor must report unexpected adverse events not listed in investigator brochure
Sponsors must identify all previously submitted IND safety reports concerning similar suspected adverse reactions
Sponsors must analyze significance of suspected adverse reactions compared to previous reports
Sponsors must report any suspected adverse reaction that is both serious and unexpected
Report adverse events as suspected reactions only if evidence suggests causal relationship with drug
Report single occurrences of uncommon events known to be strongly associated with drug exposure
Report events not commonly associated with drug exposure but uncommon in the exposed population
Sponsor must report findings from epidemiological studies suggesting significant human risk
Sponsor must report findings from pooled analyses suggesting significant human risk
Sponsor must report findings from animal testing suggesting significant human risk
Sponsor must report findings from in vitro testing suggesting significant human risk
Safety-related findings require updates to study protocol
Safety-related findings require updates to informed consent documents
Safety-related findings require updates to investigator brochure (excluding routine updates)
Sponsor must report any clinically important increase in serious suspected adverse reaction rates
Submit IND safety reports in narrative format, FDA Form 3500A, or processable electronic format
Foreign adverse reactions may be submitted on CIOMS I Form instead of FDA Form 3500A
Submit pooled analyses and overall findings from studies in narrative format
Each FDA notification must be clearly marked as 'IND Safety Report'
Submit additional requested FDA data within 15 calendar days of request
Sponsors must notify FDA of unexpected fatal/life-threatening adverse reactions within 7 calendar days
FDA may require sponsors to submit IND safety reports in different format or frequency
Sponsors must submit annual IND progress reports within 60 days of anniversary date
Sponsors must submit IND safety reports for adverse reactions in clinical studies of marketed drugs
Sponsors may propose alternative reporting formats if approved by FDA review division director
Study endpoints must be reported to FDA by sponsor as described in protocol
Serious unexpected adverse events with suspected drug causation must be reported even if part of study endpoint
Sponsor must promptly investigate all safety information received
Follow-up information to IND safety reports must be submitted when available and marked as 'Follow-up'
Initially unreported adverse events later found reportable must be submitted within 15 calendar days of determination
Provide a brief summary of the status of each study in progress and completed during previous year
Include study title, identifiers, purpose, patient population, and completion status in summary
Report total planned subjects and actual enrollment numbers by age, gender and race
Document number of completed participants and dropouts from the study
Provide brief description of study results or interim results if available
Sponsors may deny that submitted reports constitute admission of drug causing adverse events
Submit narrative or tabular summary of most frequent adverse experiences by body system
Submit summary of all IND safety reports from the past year
List all subjects who died during the investigation with cause of death
List subjects who dropped out due to adverse experiences
Describe findings related to drug actions, dose response, and bioavailability
List completed and in-progress preclinical studies with major findings
Summarize significant manufacturing or microbiological changes from past year
General investigational plan must contain information required under § 312.23(a)(3)(iv)
Submit description of investigator brochure revisions and new brochure copy when revised
Report significant Phase 1 protocol modifications from previous year not already reported
Summarize significant foreign marketing developments with the drug during past year
Notify FDA when withdrawing an IND
End all clinical investigations when IND is withdrawn
Notify all investigators and IRBs with reasons when IND is withdrawn for safety
Sponsor must submit an IND application to FDA before clinical investigation
Sponsor must comply with all requirements in parts 50 and 56 for clinical investigations
Investigators must conduct research in compliance with parts 50 and 56
IND goes into effect 30 days after FDA receipt unless clinical hold is imposed
FDA must notify sponsor in writing of the IND receipt date
Sponsor may ship drug to investigators only after 30 days from IND receipt or earlier FDA authorization
Investigators must not administer drug to humans until IND is in effect
FDA may communicate with sponsors about IND deficiencies or need for more data
FDA will provide advice on specific IND matters upon sponsor's request
FDA communications are advisory only unless accompanied by clinical hold order
No subjects may receive investigational drug when study is on clinical hold
No new subjects may be recruited when study is on clinical hold
FDA may place clinical hold on Phase 1 studies if subjects are exposed to unreasonable risk
Clinical investigators named in IND must be qualified by scientific training and experience
Investigator brochure must not be misleading, erroneous or materially incomplete
IND must contain sufficient information to assess study subject risks per 312.23
Studies for life-threatening conditions must not exclude participants based on reproductive toxicity risks
Women with reproductive potential must not include pregnant women in definition
Life-threatening illnesses must be defined as conditions with high likelihood of death unless interrupted
Gender-specific studies may be conducted under special circumstances
Single-gender studies must run concurrent studies including the other gender
FDA may place Phase 2 or 3 studies on clinical hold if conditions in b(1)(i) through b(1)(v) apply
FDA may place clinical hold if protocol design is clearly deficient for stated objectives
FDA may place expanded access IND on hold if expanded access criteria in subpart I are not satisfied
Expanded access protocols must comply with submission requirements in subpart I
FDA may place ongoing expanded access on hold if criteria are no longer satisfied
FDA may place non-adequate/well-controlled studies on hold if interfering with adequate/well-controlled studies
FDA may place non-adequate/well-controlled studies on hold if impeding enrollment in other studies
Insufficient drug quantities must not impede adequate and well-controlled investigations
Studies showing lack of effectiveness may result in clinical hold
Studies may be halted if another drug shows better benefit/risk for same indication
Studies must stop if drug is already approved for same indication and population
Sponsors must actively pursue marketing approval with due diligence
Clinical holds should only restrict new enrollment, not current participant access
FDA may place holds on investigations with informed consent exceptions under §50.24
FDA may place investigations on clinical hold if conditions in paragraphs (b)(1) or (b)(2) apply
Criteria in § 50.24 must be submitted and satisfied for informed consent exceptions
Presidential waiver is required for prior consent requirement exceptions under § 50.23(d)
FDA must discuss deficiencies that may lead to clinical holds unless patients face immediate risks
FDA must attempt to discuss and resolve issues with sponsor before issuing clinical hold
Clinical hold orders must identify affected IND studies and explain the basis for action
Division Director must provide written explanation of clinical hold within 30 days
Clinical investigations can only resume after FDA notification
Sponsor must correct deficiencies before clinical hold can be removed
Clinical hold orders may be issued by telephone or other rapid communication methods
FDA shall respond in writing to clinical hold responses within 30 calendar days
Sponsors must not proceed with clinical trials under hold until FDA notifies hold is lifted
Sponsors may request reconsideration of clinical hold decisions under § 312.48
FDA may place IND on inactive status if clinical hold exceeds 1 year
Sponsors must end all clinical investigations if IND is terminated
Sponsors must recall or dispose of unused drug supplies upon IND termination
FDA may terminate an IND if human subjects would be exposed to unreasonable risk of illness or injury
IND must contain sufficient information to assess safety of clinical investigations
Manufacturing facilities and controls must maintain appropriate standards for drug identity and quality
Clinical investigations must be conducted as described in IND protocols
Drug must not be promoted or distributed for unauthorized commercial purposes
IND submissions must not contain untrue statements or omit required material information
Sponsors must report serious and unexpected adverse experiences according to § 312.32
Sponsors must submit accurate annual reports of investigations per § 312.33
Sponsors must comply with all requirements in parts 50 and 56
INDs must not remain on inactive status for 5 years or more
Sponsors must suspend investigations placed on clinical hold under § 312.42(b)(4)
Sponsors have 30 days to respond to FDA's IND termination proposal
Sponsor may provide written explanation/correction or request conference with FDA upon notification
IND shall be terminated if sponsor does not respond within allocated time
FDA must inform sponsor in writing if explanation/correction is not accepted
Sponsor must request regulatory hearing within 10 days of receiving FDA's nonacceptance
FDA shall immediately terminate IND if investigation presents immediate danger to health
FDA may terminate an IND if it poses an unreasonable and significant risk to subjects
FDA must provide sponsor opportunity for regulatory hearing if IND is terminated
FDA may place IND on inactive status if no subjects enrolled for 2+ years
FDA must notify sponsor in writing before placing IND on inactive status
Sponsors have 30 days to respond to proposed inactive status notification
All investigators must be notified if IND is placed on inactive status
All drug stocks must be returned or disposed of when IND becomes inactive
Submit protocol amendment with investigational plan when resuming inactive IND
Wait 30 days after FDA receives protocol amendment before resuming inactive IND
Reference previously submitted information in protocol amendment if relied upon
Submit additional supporting information via information amendment if needed
IND may be terminated if inactive status continues for 5+ years
Hold meetings between sponsor and FDA to resolve questions during clinical investigation
Scientific/medical meetings shall be conducted and documented according to part 10
Free, full and open communication should occur about scientific/medical questions during clinical investigation
End-of-Phase 2 meetings must evaluate safety of proceeding to Phase 3
End-of-Phase 2 meetings must evaluate Phase 3 plan and protocols
End-of-Phase 2 meetings must assess plans for pediatric safety and effectiveness
End-of-Phase 2 meetings must identify additional information needed for marketing application
Any IND sponsor may request and obtain an end-of-Phase 2 meeting
End-of-Phase 2 meetings should be held before major Phase 3 commitments are made
Sponsor should submit Phase 3 plan info at least 1 month before end-of-Phase 2 meeting
Submission must include summaries of Phase 1 and 2 investigations
Submission must include specific protocols for Phase 3 clinical studies
Submission must include plans for pediatric studies with timeline
FDA must schedule meetings at times convenient for both FDA and sponsor
Both sponsors and FDA may bring consultants to meetings
Meetings should focus on establishing agreement on Phase 3 plan and study design
FDA must provide judgment on required pediatric studies and deferral status
FDA must record meeting agreements in minutes per §10.65 and provide to sponsor
Meeting minutes and written materials serve as permanent record of agreements
Studies conducted per agreement shall be presumed sufficient for marketing approval
Sponsor must initiate pre-NDA/BLA meeting arrangements with FDA reviewing division
Sponsor should submit meeting materials to FDA at least 1 month before pre-NDA/BLA meeting
Studies must adequately assess pediatric safety and effectiveness
Sponsor must identify adequate and well-controlled studies establishing drug effectiveness
Submit a brief summary of clinical studies in the application
Propose a format for organizing data submission
Include information on status of pediatric studies
Sponsors should first attempt to resolve disputes with the FDA division responsible for IND review
Unresolved disputes may be raised with the designated ombudsman
Begin dispute resolution with the assigned consumer safety officer
Sponsors must select qualified investigators
Sponsors must provide investigators with information needed to conduct investigations properly
Sponsors must ensure proper monitoring of investigations
Sponsors must maintain an effective IND for the investigations
Sponsors must promptly inform FDA and investigators of significant new adverse effects or risks
Sponsors should discuss scientific/medical disputes directly with reviewing officials
FDA must attempt to grant meeting requests involving important issues at mutually convenient times
End-of-Phase 2 and pre-NDA meetings shall provide forum for resolving scientific/medical disputes
FDA may invite advisory committee members or consultants to dispute resolution meetings
Sponsors may bring their own consultants to meetings
Transfer of obligations to contract research organizations must be described in writing
Written transfer must specify which obligations are being assumed by contract research organization
Contract research organizations must comply with all regulations applicable to obligations they assume
Sponsors must select investigators qualified by training and experience to investigate the drug
Sponsors shall only ship investigational drugs to participating investigators
Sponsors must obtain signed FDA Form 1572 from investigators before they begin participation
Form FDA-1572 must include investigator name and address
Form FDA-1572 must include protocol names and code numbers for studies to be conducted
Document name and address of medical schools, hospitals, and research facilities conducting clinical investigations
Document name and address of clinical laboratory facilities used in the study
Document name and address of IRB responsible for study review and approval
Investigator must conduct studies according to current protocol and notify sponsor of changes
Investigator must personally conduct or supervise the investigations
Investigator must inform subjects of investigational drug use and obtain informed consent
Investigator must report adverse events to sponsor per § 312.64
Investigator must read and understand investigator brochure including drug risks
IRB must conduct initial and continuing review/approval of clinical investigations
Investigator must promptly report all unanticipated problems involving risks to IRB
Investigator must not make research changes without IRB approval
Changes may be made without IRB approval only to eliminate immediate hazards to subjects
Investigator must provide list of all subinvestigators assisting in the investigation
Investigator must provide curriculum vitae or statement of qualifications
Investigator must have documented education, training and experience qualifying them as drug trial expert
Phase 1 investigations must include planned duration and maximum number of subjects
Phase 2/3 protocols must specify subject numbers, controls, clinical uses, demographics and testing
Investigators must provide financial disclosure information for certification requirements
Investigators must update financial information during trial and 1 year after completion
Sponsor shall select monitors qualified by training and experience
Sponsor shall monitor progress of all investigations involving exception from informed consent under §50.24
Sponsor must submit copies of public disclosures to IND file and Docket Number 95S-0158
Sponsor shall monitor investigations to identify when IRB cannot approve research under §50.24(a)
Sponsor must promptly notify FDA, investigators and IRBs in writing when research cannot be approved
Sponsor must provide investigators with investigator brochure containing §312.23(a)(5) information before study start
Sponsor shall monitor the progress of all clinical investigations under their IND
Sponsor must keep investigators informed of new observations about the drug
Important safety information must be relayed to investigators per § 312.32
Sponsor shall secure compliance or discontinue drug shipments if investigator violates requirements
Sponsor shall require non-compliant investigators to dispose of or return investigational drug
Safety updates may be distributed via brochures, reprints, reports, letters or other appropriate means
Sponsor shall review and evaluate drug safety and effectiveness evidence from investigators
Sponsor must submit safety reports to FDA as required under § 312.32
Sponsor shall submit annual investigation progress reports per § 312.33
Sponsor must discontinue investigations within 5 working days if drug poses unreasonable risk
Sponsor shall notify FDA, IRBs and investigators of investigation discontinuance
Sponsor shall maintain records of investigational drug receipt, shipment and disposition
Sponsor must maintain records of drug shipments including recipient, date, quantity and batch/code marks
Sponsor must maintain complete records of financial interests paid to clinical investigators
Sponsor must retain records for 2 years after marketing application approval
If application not approved, retain records 2 years after investigational use discontinuation
Sponsor must ensure return of unused investigational drug from investigators who discontinue participation
Sponsors shall maintain written records of investigational drug disposition
Investigators must conduct studies according to the signed investigator statement and plan
Investigators shall protect rights, safety and welfare of subjects under their care
Investigators shall control investigational drugs
Investigators shall obtain informed consent from each subject receiving the drug
Sponsors shall retain reserve samples of test articles used in bioequivalence/bioavailability studies
Sponsors shall release reserve samples to FDA upon request
Permit FDA officers to access and verify clinical investigation records and reports at reasonable times
Submit records/reports to FDA upon written request
Discontinue drug shipments to investigators who fail to maintain/provide required records
Make controlled substance records available for DEA inspection and copying upon request
Store investigational controlled substances in a securely locked, substantially constructed cabinet/enclosure
Limit access to stored investigational controlled substances
Investigator shall administer drug only to subjects under their personal supervision
Investigator shall not supply investigational drug to unauthorized persons
Investigator must maintain records of drug disposition including dates, quantity and subject use
Investigator must return unused drug supplies to sponsor when study ends
Investigator must maintain accurate case histories for each subject receiving the drug
Case histories must include signed and dated consent forms
Case history must document that informed consent was obtained before study participation
Investigators shall retain records for 2 years after marketing application approval
Investigators shall furnish all reports to the drug sponsor
Investigators must immediately report any serious adverse events to the sponsor
Adverse event reports must include assessment of possible drug causation
Serious adverse events that are study endpoints must be reported per protocol
Investigator must immediately report serious adverse events to the sponsor
Investigator must record and report non-serious adverse events according to protocol timeline
Investigator shall provide final report to sponsor after completing investigation participation
Investigator shall provide accurate financial information to sponsor for certification/disclosure
Investigator shall update financial information for changes during study and 1 year after completion
Investigator shall ensure IRB review and approval of proposed clinical study
Investigators must report all changes in research activity to the IRB promptly
Investigators must report all unanticipated problems involving subject risk to the IRB
Investigators must obtain IRB approval before making research changes except for immediate safety hazards
Investigators shall provide FDA access to inspect and copy research records upon request
Controlled substances must be stored in a securely locked, substantially constructed cabinet
Access to controlled substance storage must be limited to prevent theft or diversion
FDA must provide written notice to investigators who repeatedly fail to comply with requirements
FDA must offer investigators opportunity to explain compliance issues in writing
FDA must offer investigators option for informal conference to explain compliance issues
FDA must discontinue disqualification if investigator explanation is accepted
FDA must provide regulatory hearing opportunity if explanation is not accepted
Commissioner must evaluate all information before determining investigator disqualification
Commissioner must notify investigator when they are ineligible to receive test articles
Commissioner must notify sponsors when their investigator is ineligible
Commissioner must notify IRBs when an investigator is ineligible
Procedures must expedite development of therapies for life-threatening illnesses
Procedures must expedite development of therapies for severely-debilitating illnesses
FDA may apply flexibility in safety and effectiveness standards based on drug types and uses
FDA must notify investigators of their ineligibility determination and explain the basis
Ineligible investigators cannot conduct clinical investigations supporting FDA applications
FDA must examine applications containing data from ineligible investigators for unreliable data
FDA must notify sponsor if remaining data is inadequate after removing unreliable data
Sponsors shall have opportunity for regulatory hearing under part 16
Commissioner shall terminate IND immediately upon finding unreliable data
Commissioner must notify sponsor and IRBs of IND termination
Sponsor shall submit investigation results to FDA even if data deemed unreliable
Commissioner shall withdraw product approval if it cannot be justified after removing unreliable data
Ineligible investigators may be reinstated upon providing adequate compliance assurances
Sponsors have right to regulatory hearing before FDA on IND reinstatement
FDA shall apply flexible standards while maintaining safety and effectiveness guarantees
Drug benefits must be evaluated relative to disease severity
These procedures apply to drugs being studied for life-threatening or severely-debilitating diseases
Sponsors may request early meetings with FDA officials to review preclinical and clinical study designs
FDA may invite outside experts to early consultation meetings when appropriate
FDA reviewing officials must honor requests for meetings with scientific consultants when resources permit
Sponsors may consult FDA on applicability of procedures to specific products
Sponsors may request pre-IND meetings with FDA before initial IND submission
Pre-IND meetings must review and agree on animal study designs needed for human testing
Sponsors may request end-of-phase-1 meetings when phase 1 clinical data is available
Life-threatening conditions must have high likelihood of death or potentially fatal outcomes
Severely debilitating conditions must cause major irreversible morbidity
Reach agreement on design of phase 2 controlled clinical trials for safety and effectiveness data
Discuss design and timing of pediatric patient studies
FDA may request sponsor to submit treatment protocol after promising phase 2 results
Treatment protocols must be reviewed under procedures in §§ 312.305 and 312.320
Treatment protocol remains active while marketing application data is assembled and reviewed
Clinical hold may be placed on ongoing protocols per § 312.42(b)(3)(ii)
FDA shall document agreements reached during end-of-phase 1 meetings using procedures from § 312.47(b)(1)
FDA shall evaluate medical risk-benefit judgment for final marketing approval decisions
FDA shall consider if drug benefits outweigh known and potential risks
FDA shall seek advice from outside expert consultants or advisory committees for end-of-phase 1 marketing approvals
FDA must notify relevant advisory committee members when marketing application is filed and available for review
FDA must explain in complete response letter why agreed research design results were insufficient for approval
Complete response letter must include advisory committee recommendations about the application
Marketing applications must comply with requirements in part 314 or part 600
FDA may request sponsor agreement for Phase 4 postmarketing studies upon approval
Phase 4 studies may include different doses, schedules, populations or longer duration than Phase 2
FDA may conduct focused regulatory research on critical rate-limiting aspects
FDA must monitor progress and conduct of clinical trials for covered drugs
Informed consent must be obtained from trial participants per Part 50
Institutional review board approval is required per Part 56
Animal studies must be reviewed before initial human testing
IND safety reports must be submitted to monitor adverse drug experiences
Safety update reports must be submitted during marketing application review
Post-marketing adverse reaction reports must be submitted per 314.80
Imported investigational drugs must be subject to an active IND under § 312.40
US consignee for imported investigational drugs must be the IND sponsor
US consignee may be a qualified investigator named in the IND
Foreign sponsor's domestic agent must be identified in the IND with defined responsibilities
Exported investigational drugs must comply with laws of receiving country
Recipients of exported investigational drugs must be investigators in an approved IND study
Drugs exported to EU/EEA countries must comply with the laws of the receiving country
Drugs exported without an IND are exempt from label requirements in § 312.6(a)
Exporters must send certification email to OGPSExecSec@fda.hhs.gov when first exporting drug
Export certification must include drug trade name, generic name, and dosage form
Exporters must maintain records documenting compliance with certification requirements
Exported drug must meet foreign purchaser's specifications
Outer shipping package must be labeled to show it is intended for export from the United States
Drug must not be sold or offered for sale in the United States
Clinical investigation must be conducted in accordance with § 312.120
Drug must be manufactured, processed, packaged and held in substantial conformity with GMP
Drug must not be adulterated per section 501(a)(1), (a)(2)(A), (a)(3), (c), or (d)
Drug must not present imminent hazard to public health in US or foreign country
Drug must be labeled in accordance with foreign country's laws
Provide written explanation why compliance with specified paragraphs is not feasible or contrary to best interests
Obtain written statement from importing country's government official agreeing with exporter's explanation
Official statement must confirm drug is for national emergency stockpile use only
Official statement must describe the potential national emergency warranting the export
Obtain written statement showing Secretary of HHS agrees with importing country's findings
Direct requests for Secretary's statement to Secretary's Operations Center
Export requests may be submitted by fax to 202-619-7870
Export requests may be submitted by email to HHS.SOC@hhs.gov
FDA authorization must be obtained before proceeding with drug exportation
For emergency exports, provide written statement explaining why compliance with certain paragraphs is not feasible
For emergency exports, provide documentation from importing country's government official
Requests for emergency determinations must be sent to Secretary's Operations Center
Emergency requests may be submitted by FAX to 202-619-7870
Emergency requests may be submitted by email to HHS.SOC@hhs.gov
Exportation cannot occur if the IND for the clinical investigation is no longer in effect
Exportation cannot occur if requirements in section 802(b)(1), (f), or (g) are not met
Foreign clinical studies must be conducted in accordance with good clinical practice (GCP)
GCP must ensure data and reported results are credible and accurate
GCP must protect the rights, safety and well-being of trial subjects
New insulin and antibiotic products may be exported for investigational use under section 801(e)(1)
Exported investigational drugs must comply with importing country laws
GCP includes review and approval of clinical trials
Obtain independent ethics committee approval before initiating a study
Ethics committee must conduct continuing review of ongoing studies
Obtain documented informed consent from subject or legal representative before study initiation
FDA may validate study data through onsite inspection if deemed necessary
FDA will examine data from studies even if they don't meet conditions in paragraph (a)(1)
Marketing approval based solely on foreign clinical data must comply with § 314.106
Submit description of actions taken to ensure research conformed to GCP
Submit investigator qualifications documentation
Provide description of research facilities
Submit detailed protocol summary and study results
Provide description of drug substance and product used in study
Submit evidence that effectiveness studies are adequate and well-controlled per §314.126
Provide name and address of IEC that reviewed the study
Sponsor must maintain records of IEC members' names and qualifications
Sponsor must make IEC member records available for agency review upon request
Study must include summary of IEC's approval decision or favorable opinion
Study must describe how informed consent was obtained from participants
Study must describe any incentives provided to study participants
Sponsor must maintain signed investigator commitments to GCP compliance
Sponsor must make investigator GCP commitments available for agency review upon request
Sponsors may request waivers from FDA for applicable requirements through IND or application amendments
Waiver requests must include explanation of why compliance is unnecessary or unachievable
FDA may grant waivers if determined to be in the interest of public health
Records for foreign clinical studies supporting marketing applications must be retained for 2 years after agency decision
Records for foreign clinical studies supporting only INDs must be retained for 2 years after IND submission
FDA shall not disclose existence of investigational new drug applications unless previously publicly disclosed
Data disclosure for new drug INDs must follow confidentiality provisions in § 314.430
Data disclosure for biological product INDs must follow provisions in §§ 601.50 and 601.51
FDA shall provide IND safety reports to individuals who received the investigational drug upon request
Requests for public IND information under informed consent exceptions must be submitted via FOIA
Sponsors must send initial IND submissions to either CDER or CBER based on product regulation
Send CDER-regulated drug product IND submissions to CDER Central Document Room in Beltsville, MD
Send CDER-regulated biological product IND submissions to CDER Central Document Room in Beltsville, MD
Send CBER-regulated biological product IND submissions to CBER Document Control Center
The responsible Center must inform sponsors which CDER/CBER division is responsible for their IND
IND amendments and reports must be sent to the appropriate center and marked for the responsible division
The outside wrapper of each submission shall state the content type (IND Application, Protocol Amendment, etc)
Export-related IND correspondence must be submitted to the International Affairs Staff office
CDER and CBER shall maintain guidance document lists on the Internet
Guidance document lists must be published annually in the Federal Register
Label drugs for in vitro or animal research with warning 'Not for use in humans'
Label biological products for in vitro diagnostic tests with specified warning text
Verify consignee regularly conducts laboratory tests before shipping investigational drugs
Verify shipped drugs will be used only for in vitro or animal laboratory research
Submit requests for CBER lists to specified FDA address
Maintain records showing name and address of experts receiving drug shipments
Maintain records of date, quantity and batch/code mark for each shipment
Keep shipment records under paragraph (a)(1)(i) for 2 years
Allow FDA officers to access and verify shipment records upon request
FDA may terminate shipping authorization if sponsor fails to comply with conditions
FDA must notify shipper of compliance findings and allow opportunity for correction
Drug shipper shall ensure return of all unused drug supplies from investigators when investigation ends or terminates
Alternative disposition of unused drugs requires written authorization from the shipper
Alternative drug disposition must not expose humans to risks directly or indirectly
Shipper shall maintain records of any alternative drug disposition
Expanded access requirements apply to investigational new drugs and approved drugs with limited REMS availability
FDA must determine if patients have a serious or immediately life-threatening disease or condition
FDA must verify no comparable or satisfactory alternative therapy exists
Immediately life-threatening conditions must have likelihood of death within months
Serious diseases must substantially impact day-to-day functioning
Clinical judgment must determine disease seriousness based on survival and functioning impacts
Drugs must be intended to diagnose, monitor, or treat patient diseases or conditions
Patient benefit must justify potential risks of treatment use
Expanded access must not interfere with clinical investigations for marketing approval
Submit expanded access request as new IND or protocol amendment to existing IND
Include FDA Form 1571 cover sheet with expanded access submission
Provide rationale for drug use including list of available therapeutic options
Explain why investigational drug is preferable to available therapeutic options
Patient selection criteria or individual patient disease/condition description must be documented
Drug administration method, dose, and therapy duration must be specified
Manufacturing facility details must be described
Chemistry and manufacturing controls must ensure proper drug identification, quality, purity and strength
Pharmacology and toxicology information must demonstrate reasonable drug safety
Clinical procedures and monitoring methods must be described to evaluate effects and minimize risks
Expanded access submissions must be clearly marked 'EXPANDED ACCESS SUBMISSION'
Physicians directing investigational drug administration must comply with investigator responsibilities in subpart D
Entities submitting expanded access INDs must comply with sponsor responsibilities in subpart D
Investigators must report adverse drug events to the sponsor
Investigators must ensure informed consent requirements of part 50 are met
Investigators must obtain IRB review consistent with part 56 requirements
Investigators must maintain accurate case histories
Sponsors must submit IND safety reports to FDA
Sponsors must submit annual reports when IND continues for 1+ year
Sponsors must ensure physicians are qualified to administer investigational drugs
Sponsors must provide physicians with investigator brochure if one exists
Sponsors must maintain effective IND for expanded access use
Sponsors must maintain adequate drug disposition records
FDA may permit investigational drug use for individual patient treatment by licensed physician
Expanded access IND goes into effect 30 days after FDA receipt or earlier FDA notification
Emergency expanded access use can only begin upon FDA reviewing official authorization
FDA may place any expanded access IND or protocol on clinical hold
Physician must determine investigational drug risk is not greater than disease risk
FDA must determine patient cannot obtain drug under another IND/protocol
Expanded access submission must demonstrate criteria compliance with supporting information
Sponsors may amend existing IND to include protocol for individual patient expanded access
FDA may permit investigational drug use for smaller patient populations than typical treatment IND
Licensed physicians must obtain sponsor permission for FDA to reference IND information
Treatment is limited to single course unless FDA authorizes multiple/chronic therapy
Licensed physician or sponsor must provide FDA written report at treatment conclusion
Sponsors must provide a summary of expanded access use results including adverse effects
FDA may require sponsors to monitor individual patient expanded access for extended duration use
Emergency expanded access requests can be made by telephone, fax or electronic communications
Biological drug emergency requests should be directed to CBER Office of Communication
Non-biological drug emergency requests should be directed to CDER Division of Drug Information
After-hours emergency requests must be directed to FDA Emergency Call Center
Licensed physician/sponsor must explain how expanded access use meets requirements of §§ 312.305 and 312.310
Submit expanded access submission within 15 working days of FDA authorization
Expanded access may be needed when drug is not being developed due to rare disease patient recruitment issues
Expanded access may be needed when patients cannot participate in existing clinical trials
Expanded access may be needed for approved drugs no longer marketed for safety reasons
Expanded access may be needed for drugs with same active moiety as unavailable approved products
Criteria in § 312.305(a) must be met for expanded access
Evidence must show drug safety at proposed dose and duration to justify clinical trial
Preliminary clinical evidence of drug effectiveness must be available
Expanded access submission must include information satisfying FDA criteria
Submission must state whether drug is being developed and describe patient population
For non-developed drugs, sponsor must explain why development is not current and future conditions
For drugs in clinical trial, sponsor must explain why patients need expanded access
FDA must review IND annual reports to determine if expanded access should continue
FDA may permit investigational drugs for widespread treatment use
Sponsors must monitor expanded access protocols to ensure physician compliance
FDA may request sponsors submit an IND/protocol as patient enrollment increases
FDA must evaluate if expanded access interferes with clinical drug development
Criteria in § 312.305(a) must be met for treatment IND approval
Drug must be investigated in controlled clinical trial under IND for expanded access use
Sponsor must actively pursue marketing approval for expanded access use with due diligence
For serious conditions, evidence must include data from phase 3 trials or compelling phase 2 data
For life-threatening conditions, evidence must show reasonable effectiveness without unreasonable risk
Expanded access submission must satisfy FDA criteria in §312.305(a)
Expanded access submission must meet requirements of §312.305(b)
Sponsors must monitor treatment protocols to ensure physician compliance
Sponsors must ensure licensed physicians comply with the treatment protocol
Sponsors must ensure physicians comply with investigator regulations
Only licensed physicians may participate in treatment protocols
